history.content:
Personally didn't find it very directly useful to AI/ML/Robotics, but 170 is pretty core for anyone who wants to call themselves a computer scientist. 

The material covered is quite important, but if you really want to avoid taking the course, I would recommend at least reading through the book and self-learning the material. If you have taken 61B/70, it should not be too hard to learn the first half of the material (Divide and Conquer, Graph/Search, and Dynamic Programming algorithms). The more theoretical stuff (P/NP, Reductions, etc.) might be harder to grasp, but there are plenty of resources out there on those topics if you are interested.

Personally didn't find it very directly useful to AI/ML/Robotics, but 170 is pretty core for anyone who wants to call themselves a computer scientist. 

The material covered is quite important, but if you really want to avoid taking the course, I would recommend at least reading through the book and self-learning the material. If you have taken 61B/70, it should not be too hard to learn the first half of the material (Divide and Conquer, Graph/Search, and Dynamic Programming algorithms). The more theoretical stuff (P/NP, Reductions, etc.) might be harder to grasp, but there are plenty of resources out there on those topics.

Personally didn't find it very directly useful to AI/ML/Robotics, but 170 is pretty core for anyone who wants to call themselves a computer scientist. 

The material covered is quite important, but if you really want to avoid taking the course, I would recommend at least reading through the book and self-learning the material. If you have taken 61B/70, it should not be too hard to learn the first half of the material. The more theoretical stuff (P/NP) might be harder to grasp, but there are plenty of resources out there on those topics.
Personally didn't find it very directly useful to AI/ML/Robotics, but 170 is pretty core for anyone who wants to call themselves a computer scientist.

170 is absolutely fundamental to EECS. The ways of thinking are directly relevant to most areas, including the whole AI/ML/Control/Optimization/Robotics/SP/Comm supercluster. 

You have to remember that you are being educated for a 40 year career with a lifetime of learning, not your first job or interview or project. The foundations are absolutely critical long term.

Is CS170 worth it? I did well in CS70 with a massive amount of work... dont find theory very interesting... I really liked 188 and 189 and plan to take more courses that directly relate to those areas... is CS170 worth it and why?
history.subject: CS170 for AI/ML/Robotics
